results.title: Someday you'll find her, Charlie Brown. It's your first kiss, Charlie Brown.
results.brief_description: In “Someday you’ll find her, Charlie Brown”, Charlie becomes captivated by a beautiful girl on television. Despite Linus’ opinion that Charlie falls in love every week, he agrees to help Charlie in his mission. After many false leads and a property protected by a fierce cat, they finally track her down, only to discover she has more in common with Linus who promptly falls in love with her also. Featuring the voices of Grant Wehr, Melissa Strawmeyer, Jennifer Gaffin and Earl Reilly. Produced by Lee Mendelson and Bill Melendez. In “It’s your first kiss, Charlie Brown”, Charlie and Linus act as the queen’s attendants and Charlie is scared about the prospect of having to kiss Heather, the ‘little red-headed girl’ and homecoming queen. Featuring the voices of Arrin Skelley, Michelle Muller, Laura Planting, Ronald Hendrix and Daniel Anderson. Produced by Bill Melendez.

results.title: Somebody waiting
results.creator_credit: Dick Snider, Hal Riney and University of California, Los Angeles
results.brief_description: An evocative and poignant view of the staff of Corcoran Cottage as they attempt, with some success, to make life more stimulating and comfortable for the severely mentally and physically handicapped children of Corcoran Cottage, California.

results.title: Somebody that I used to know
results.brief_description: One of the first music videos to go viral in the age of the internet, ‘Somebody That I Used to Know’ (2011) by Gotye (and featuring Kimbra) has been viewed over 1.3 billion times on YouTube.

constellations_primary.name: Viral music videos
constellations_primary.description: Gotye's 'Somebody that I used to know' was one of the internet's most viral music videos, seconded only to Queen Bey's 'Singles Ladies'.

results.description: One of the first music videos to go viral in the age of the internet, ‘Somebody That I Used to Know’ (2011) by Gotye (and featuring Kimbra) has been viewed over 1.3 billion times on YouTube. The use of body paint and early animation technique stop motion helped drive the track to a No.1 hit in the US and Australia, as well as countless comedic parodies and rip-offs in the intervening years.
description_for_label: One of the first music videos to go viral in the age of the internet, ‘Somebody That I Used to Know’ (2011) by Gotye (and featuring Kimbra) has been viewed over 1.3 billion times on YouTube. The use of body paint and early animation technique stop motion helped drive the track to a No.1 hit in the US and Australia, as well as countless comedic parodies and rip-offs in the intervening years.

images.alt_text: A close-up of Gotye, who has slightly pink lips and chestnut curly shoulder length hair, he's squinting

results.title: Somebody now: 'Nobody's Children' seven years on
results.creator_credit: David Goldie, Christopher McCullough and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description: This film follows on from Nobody’s children”, an expose of homeless youth in inner Sydney. Seven years later, the producers have located two of the children from the original film in order to discover if things have improved for them and what impact being homeless had on their lives. The strong message that emerges is that even though the homeless person may experience a change in their socio-economic status at some point, this does not change the person they are inside. They still face the same emotional issues and burdens they had while they were homeless; unless they receive help, they will simply perpetuate the same situations over and over.

results.title: Somebody I Used To Know – Gotye ft. Kimbra
results.brief_description: One of the first music videos to go viral in the age of the internet, ‘Somebody That I Used to Know’ (2011) by Gotye (and featuring Kimbra) has been viewed over 1.3 billion times on YouTube.
results.title_for_label: Somebody I Used To Know – Gotye ft. Kimbra
results.description: One of the first music videos to go viral in the age of the internet, ‘Somebody That I Used to Know’ by Gotye (and featuring Kimbra) has been viewed over 1.3 billion times on YouTube. The use of body paint and early animation technique stop motion helped drive the track to a No.1 hit in the US and Australia, as well as countless comedic parodies and rip-offs in the intervening years.
description_for_label: One of the first music videos to go viral in the age of the internet, ‘Somebody That I Used to Know’ by Gotye (and featuring Kimbra) has been viewed over 1.3 billion times on YouTube. The use of body paint and early animation technique stop motion helped drive the track to a No.1 hit in the US and Australia, as well as countless comedic parodies and rip-offs in the intervening years.

results.title: Some women of Marrakech
results.creator_credit: Melissa L. Davies and Granada International Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Disappearing world”.
An all-woman camera team gives a feminist perspective on the realities of Islamic women’s lives in Marrakech. Shows the taboos and their rights and obligations under Islamic Law from a western point of view. Includes many interviews and documents a real Islamic wedding and the traditions that are followed. Commentary by Gill Shepherd.

results.title: Some secrets should be told
results.creator_credit: Henry Felt, Jack Churchill and Family Information Systems and Resource Communications
results.brief_description: Susan Linn and her two hand puppets, Cat-a-Lion and Audrey, discuss an experience of sexual abuse that happened to Audrey’s young friend Elizabeth. They differentiate sexual abuse from normal relationships, emphasize that some secrets must be told, suggest who children might talk to, and point out that it was not the child’s fault.

results.title: Some people have to suffer
results.creator_credit: Christopher Pinney and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: This film documents a community’s struggle to survive in the face of government indifference and the political and financial clout of industrial developers. In 1953 the residents of Bridgeview, British Columbia, were promised sewers; following years of debate, frustration, meetings and verbiage, construction started in 1977. The film interviews some of the residents, who state their opinions frankly both to the camera and at meetings. When the film was shown at the Habitat conference in Vancouver, 1976, press coverage noted: “The Third World is merely twenty miles from the site of Habitat.” Narration: Boyce Richardson.
